I don't have time for much tv but nothing keeps me from Criminal Minds.  The character development, the stories, the actors, everything about it is fantastic.
There is graphic and suggestive violence, and some of the subject matter is very disturbing, very disturbing.  Definitely not for children.
This particular season was at the series peak.  I can't wait to buy the season.  For that matter, I am having trouble waiting for the new season to start.  After all,.....dark screen, BANG!

Season 4 was awesome. Can't wait to see on DVD so i can re watch all my favourite episodes... Pact with action, thrilling and team dynamics - I am sure all fans will enjoy deeply... Sept 8 is not soon enough!

Must have for all fans

Of the four seasons, this season may be the best.  With more dark storylines, the series follow Rossi, Hotchner, Prentiss, Morgan, Reid, Jareau, and Garcia as they deal with the evil side of human nature and more of their own personal stories, connections, and demons.

The fourth season fleshes out these characters and their interdependence on each other.  An excellent team takes time to build and bond.  The season brings this to full circle, especially in the last few episodes where the plots begin to build toward an explosive climax in the season finale.

The promise of new life with Jennifer Jareau's baby boy is a subplot.  As Jareau deals with motherhood, she faces her emotions and fears, especially as she contemplates her child and what the future may hold.

Some of the best episodes are-Minimal Loss with Luke Perry; Instincts and Memoriam which features Dr. Reid's memories of a murder from his childhood, Masterpiece with Jason Alexander,  Soul Mates which gives love your neighbor a sinister twist; Roadkill which is a taut thriller with a surprise; Amplification features an analytical lecture from Reid as he is exposed to a deadly substance; and  To Hell...And Back is the season finale with enough horror, disgust and death for a whole season.  Death takes no holiday in this episode.  Unfortunately, you will never look at that Christmas ham the same way after watching this episode.

This series is for mature minds.  It is definitely not for younger children.

OMG the Season Four finale was fantastic. I am an absolute avid fan of Criminal Minds. I have Seasons 1-3 on DVD. I can't wait for Season Four to come out. I can't tell you why if you haven't watched this season I don't want to ruin anything for you. I am already excited about Season Five. If you like FBI/Profiler type searies then this one is by far the best and a must have for any serious collector. If you are a new collector or have been living in a cave somewhere and never heard of Criminal Minds please see Seasons 1-3 don't just watch Season Four they must all be watched to fully appreciate the chracters and the plots.

Criminal Minds is an outstanding TV show, it has a mesmerizing effect on me as a viewer, every season it simply gets better and better, it is brilliantly written, acted and directed.  Can't wait for season 4 to be released on dvd.  This show has a huge fan base down here in Costa Rica, Central America.  Viva Criminal Minds!
Can anyone tell me when this product will be released? I'm not in the states so dvd is my only chance to see it.

I am an avid watcher and fan of "Criminal Minds." The 4th season is phenomenal. Every season I say to myself, "It can't get any better than this," and every season it goes above and beyond the previous one. Hard to believe, but true. The season finale this time was shocking!!!! It is worth it just to get the 4th season to see the final episode!!!

I am an avid watcher of the Criminal Minds series and I would have to say that this is the best season yet and it isn't even over with.  It is not very often that one can say that every single episode was absolutely amazing.  Although there was one episode which didn't meet up to the standards of the rest.
As for the rest of the season, thanks to amazing writers and directors, this show has managed to show me things I never thought possible.  For example, I am used to seeing James Alexander as creepy, I think that was the whole point of George on Seinfield.  But the character that Jason Alexander played was truly amazing, creepy in just the right way, but truly an unsub worthy of the team.
One shadow I do have about this season was the appearance of the character Jordan.  At her first appearance and initial interaction with Morgan you believe that this character could uphold the standard that J.J., actress A.J. Cook, carries out in her performance.  But sadly after the first spark, her performance is quite a disappoint.  In fact, I usually watched the episode in hopes of avoiding her character all together.  Perphaps I am just to fond of J.J.'s character and thought biasedly at seeing her go.  But I don't doubt the relief I felt as seeing her return.
I can't wait to see the final shows of the season and I already plan on purchasing the DVD when it comes availble.  I hightly recommend it to those looking for intrigue, humor and drama all in one show.

Entertaining, yes.  Typical Hollywood BS, yes.  Over all an enjoyable show to watch.  I think one of the main reasons I like it is because there isn't a bunch of nutty stunts every episode.  I mean that is really refreshing when it seems so many shows rely on over the top stunts or plots.  Plus the over all concept pulls you in.  When they focus on this material, it is always more interesting.  As far as my little beefs, they are minor, its just you see them in every episode, so they wear on me.  Garcia is a joke.  What she does is a joke, her character is a joke. And maybe that is the joke?  They should have killed her when they had the chance.  BAU always on they scene when the catch the unsub.  I mean its like the other cops don't even exist.  They always solve the case quickly.  It would be nice, to have a few not get solved.  Finally, four seasons and five team members have been directly involved with the cases.  Its a bit much.  I get why they do these things (except Garcia), but for me, none of them work for how often it happens.

Again, over all entertaining.  Also, I think Thomas Gibson's character is top-notch.  His no nonsense approach is great.  Clearly the strongest one in the group.  Plus he isn't a walking talking cliche like Mark Harmon in NCIS.

Episode was well done. I watched it because of my interest in Dissociative Identity Disorder as depicted by a character in the episode.
Of course this was just another sensationalized characterization of a victim of a mental illness being criminalized which in reality is rare. The majority of people diagnosed with Dissociative Disorders are victims of crimes and not the perpetrators. How I wish the writers would at least once portray those suffering mental illness as victims they are. Sad and inacurate portrayal, but full of suspense.

this season is very personal for the team. Hotch has so much going on this season that it's not even fun. Rossi gets to interview a killer looking for revenge against him and deals with the murder of a fan of his. Reid has to deal with memories for a murder of a child when he was four. Derik shares his experience of losing his father with a detective. Emily investigates the murder of an old friend of hers by priest. J.J. tells the team that she's pregnant and deal with the problems of there job and being a new mom. the agent that she gets to cover for her on leave, learns that being apart of the BAU is not easy. Garcia even gets to profile a little and she learns it's not for her.

When there is a serious case involving serial killers, serial rapists, pedophiles and serial child abductors the local authorities call for help. Who do they call, BAU, the behavioral analysis unit of the FBI. They come in, create a profile that leads them to the unknown subject (Unsub) committing the crimes. Season 4, sees some interesting changes. JJ gets pregnant, and a new person temporally takes her place on the team. There is an amazing yet disturbing episode involving a terrorist attack with a particularly deadly form of anthrax. The scariest part or most disturbing, is that this could happen right here in our back yard. If you've seen prior seasons, you might find this season a little less disturbing then past seasons. Either that, or after watching 4 seasons in a row, this stuff is less disturbing to me. Maybe, I have become desensitized to it. Either way, it's a great season, with a lot of plot twists, a lot of action and a great ending to the season 3 cliffhanger. There is a wonderful 2 part episode in which Reed has to reconcile something that happened during with his childhood. Jane Lynch returns as his mother, once again proving what a great actress she really is.

If you are a fan, I highly recommend this season. If not, check it out, you might like it. Though if you are not fan, why are you reading this?

However, for those who don't mind the raw, real feel of a Crime Drama this is the series for you.

As we all know Prentiss comes and goes because of her "other job" so we won't see much of her in this season.  J.J. is back in full, thank the Lord, and this pretty much is like all other seasons, excellent.  While there is no real REAPER type character in this season, you get a TON of episodes, far more than 99% of good shows out there (2X-3X the amount of Dexter season episodes) and almost all are well written.

You just have to own all the seasons of this show.  If you like SVU you will realize how much you missed out wasting your time watching that show over this - and I was a SUV addict.  Far better acting, far more interesting shows, but the only downside is the CLEARANCE RATE.

The one thing I have always disliked about Criminal Minds is how many UNSUBS they catch, and quickly.  The odds of solving a homicide are about 60% nationwide.  Additionally, the BAU or BSU of the FBI does not handle half the cases they actually depict here.  Sure they give the obligatory "we've been invited" tagline, but most jurisdictions do not want the FBI handling their cases, especially within 24 hours.

"Wheels up in Thirty" - as a former federal investigator, I can assure you that they do not have a private jet, they fly coach - and cheap.  The FBI does not have a private landing strip for the BAU and to have a plane ready, with pilot and gas at the ready, would be impossible.  At best they arrive next day.  They never show anyone packing, just the stuff on their backs???

But those nit picky things aside, great show and it will me missed when off the air.  The X-Files of the 2000's.

I don't know if it's me, or what? But I purchased this item new, and I have had trouble with the menu. The first one I received, the menu would not select, or open an episode, and when I pushed play it skipped to the last episode. The seller sent me a replacement copy, but I am still having problems with the menu on the second copy, I literally have to shut the movie off, and restart to be able to scroll through the movies and select an episode. Very frustrating. Poor manufacturing!

I don't see any other comments regarding this problem, and I own Seasons 1-3 without this problem. So, it's not my equipment. I've also read comments regarding Seasons 5-6 regarding poor manufacturing, what's up with that?

I don't blame the shipper at all, but the manufacture. Obviously, not adding subtitles to save on costs, and then charging a lot of money, is very surprising with all the technology available, just being cheapsakes...?

PS. I love Criminal Minds, the Cast and Crew makes the Show, I hope the producers know this. Unfortunately, the manufacturing concerns me, and even though I want to purchase Seasons 5 & 6, I don't think it's worth the money.

I have never seen this show so rented the last seson to see what it was all about. From what I read about the series from comments on the complete series led me to think that it looked like profiling except people were found guilty by this superior intelligent group and all us dumb people are required to fall in line and believe them. I found it exceptionally entertaining. The story plot was exceptional and the acting and drama as well. However several things were disturbing if the series is supposed to convince the average person that a group working in secret and going about investigating people based on profiling are smart enough to do it without public oversight.

1. All the supposedly criminals died so there was never a trial
2. Only the word of the agents was used to explain what happened.
3. They could say anything they wanted regardless whether or not it was true.

But still the entertaining value made this fairy tale worthwhile to watch if you like Nancy Drew or Agathy Christie.

I love "Criminal Minds." Being completely honest, the fourth season is probably my least favorite season, and I still really enjoyed it. There are a lot of excellent episodes centered on Dr. Reid (Matthew Gray Gubler, who I must say), which are always enjoyable episodes. Wil Wheaton appears as a victim. Mitch Pileggi appears as an unsub who you can't help but feel bad for. JJ (AJ Cook) takes a leave of absence and is replace by a woman who just might be sexier (Meta Golding). Jason Alexander appears as an evil genius in a role that is oh, so much fun for the math nerds, and later returns to direct an episode. There was just so much to enjoy in this season. I recommend it to everybody.

For as long as I can remember, TV crime dramas have been a part of my viewing experiences.  From Hill Street Blues, to Law & Order, to NYPD Blue, I've always found them compelling.  Now with influx of CSI and the science driven genre of investigative police work, there is one show that I think stands alone - Criminal Minds.

Any fan of psychological thrillers like the Hannibal Lector movies, Mr. Brooks, or any number of other movies that raise the hair on your neck, will appreciate this series.  Not only does it delve into the minds of the killer to explain how "monsters" are created, but also into the minds of the FBI BAU (Behavior Analysis Unit) team members that track them down and bring them to justice.  The series is emotional, personal, and always intriguing in it's exploration into human nature and the goods and evils it is capable of.  Top notch acting and original writing drive this series with excellent performances by Thomas Gibson as SSU Aaron Hotchner "Hotch" as the deeply introspective team leader, former soap opera star Shemar Moore, showing surprising range as an actor, as SSU Agent Morgan, and Joe Mantegna as the legendary SSU Agent, Joe Rossi, returning to slay the demons of his past failures.

The series is disturbing at times in it's content, but always innovative and informing in looking into the minds of serial killers and the heros that risk their lives tracking them down...

If you like Criminal Minds, you will like this season.  It has yet to become repetitive or dull, and this Season contains some of my favorite episodes yet.  Small critique: the season finale was not as good as the finale to season three, but it was still good and of course my taste is subjective.

The international delivery service took 4 months to deliver this season boxset to me - a transatlantic camel caravan would have done better -  I am so getting a huge discount out of them for that! I have been looking forward several months to watch those - and I was not cheated by the series team. Great plots, good acting, balanced approach mixing gritty story lines with wit, compassion and wisdom. I am so thrilled that there are some series that do not slide into cheap "let's show them some nudity and teens fun so we could get better ratings" attitude. One of the TV shows no one could call a "guilty pleasure". Not enough of those around lately, unfortunately.

After a riveting cliff hanger for season three, "Criminal Minds" returns delivering on what was promised in the 3rd season.

Hotch(Thomas Gibson) and his team tackle a variety of compelling cases including a serial rapist/murderer who mysteriously begins claiming new victims leaving his DNA behind AFTER his death ("Angel Maker")and Reid (Matthew Gaye Gublur)begins to suspect that his father may have something to do with the unsolved abduction of a boy that he played little leage with years before in Las Vegas.

There have been a number of reviews suggesting that "Criminal Minds" became predictable during the 4th season. I'd disagree as I found the writers/producers willing to tackle difficult multi-part stories with unusual twists that were the equal of earlier seasons. Having watched the 4th season randomly with the second and third, I found the quality of the writing/production/acting to be as high as the previous seasons.

I did find the last two episodes of the 4th season to have a great set up but I found it implausable (I don't want to spoil it for you but there were too many inconsistencies. If you PM me I'll gladly discuss them)but the conclusion did set up a nice cliffhanger for season 5 which was nicely resolved. There were a couple of episodes that also left threads hanging (for example "Demonology" never properly tied together how the death of a priest in Spain was truly tied into the three deaths in the U.S. unless I missed something)but I suspect it probably had to do with material cut for time constraints (I didn't look at the deleted scene for this episode so perhaps the info is there)and life often has loose ends. The rest of the episodes are taunt, well written and resolve the major issues nicely so one or two stumbles can be forgiven particularly on a show that is this tightly plotted.

The extras include a number of featurettes including "Working the Scene" that gives us a lot of behind-the-scenes information on 11 episodes. We also get deleted scenes, profiles and a gag reel. My only other complaint is that this doesn't have subtitles (although it is close captioned so those with devices that can decode the close captioning can enjoy them)for English that you can access while watching the episodes (handy when there are distractions in the background).

Recommended.
